title: Sri Lanka treasury to curb government spending ahead of IMF deal
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka Treasury will issue a new circular t to curb government spending to tighten fiscal policies, the finance ministry secretary said on Tuesday to face the financial crisis ahead of discussion with the International Monetary Fund next week.

The move comes after the island nation officially announced it cannot pay its foreign debts and interest payments – amounting to a sovereign debt default – because the government had run out of foreign reserves. The central bank and treasury are now in the process to restructure the foreign debts.
“We will be issuing a new circular to all the line ministries to reduce the government spending,” Treasury Secretary K M Siriwardena told a media briefing.

He said the finance ministry has not decided on any specific budget cuts at the moment including the President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s government to reinstate fertilizer subsidy and a total of 10,000 rupees for 3.1 million families.
Siriwardena admitted that the budget deficit has risen sharply in the last two years due to high government spending and lower revenue.
“We have to raise revenue as well. Our revenue are now at single digit compared to the GDP,” Siriwardena said.
Sri Lanka’s sovereign debt default was expected earlier than this as the authorities failed to have proper policies to address the lapses including key structural reforms.
The government has been worried about its popularity and postponed many tough policy decisions including tax hikes and streamlined spending. (Colombo/April 12/2022)
